posts.name: Ryan Fortner
posts.cooked:
We are using a trapezoidal motion profile & integrated SparkMax closed loop PID controller to control a cascading elevator, and understand how to lay everything out in code but are a bit confused on how to tune the feedforward values. We’ve spent several hours working on this, including following the WPILib tuning instructions , ReCalc, and SysID routine.

The elevator falls back down with gravity on its own, but we still managed to set up a SysID routine. This was our first approach. We ran all four tests, one right after the other, and got the following data: image 1920×1121 164 KB As you could probably imagine these constants did not do much good. I’m not sure what the negative gravity constant was caused by, even though it’s such a small value it could possibly be considered zero? We ran the routine multiple times yielding about the same results each time.

image 1920×1121 164 KB

image 1920×1121 164 KB

We also tried manually tuning constants but are confused on how to tune kG and kS independently. As far as I understand, kG can be found by slowly increasing voltage until the elevator starts to move vertically? How can kS be found? Does the elevator’s backdrive have an effect on those values? If so how could we account for this?

We’d really appreciate any help, explanations, or suggestions at all. Please see our code below:

Go to setpoint command , Elevator subsystem

link_counts.title: Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Your data look fine but it appears you applied torque-current control during the routine instead of voltage control.  Was this intentional?

The different control modes do very different things and I suggest you read the documentation carefully!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ryan Fortner
posts.cooked:
Definitely not intentional.

During the routine we’re applying voltage through REVlib’s method setVoltage … I’m not sure how we could have applied torque-current control… unless I am mistaken?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
That’s very strange, indeed.  I can’t think of anything else that causes those diagnostic plots, though, and those are a perfect match for the result of running a current sweep/step instead of a voltage one.

Edit:  I guess it could be that the “smart current limit” is causing this behavior.  Iirc on default settings that limit scales linearly with rotor velocity, so if you’re always being current-limited the test might behave as if you were sweeping the current.  Doesn’t explain why the step test is constant-acceleration, though, unless the scaling is based on the commanded duty cycle and not on the rotor velocity…

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ryan Fortner
posts.cooked:
Would disabling the current limit (setting it to 0) be safe during the routine?

Also, I don’t feel that I fully understand how I could manually tune Kg and Ks. Is it correct to slowly increase voltage until just before elevator begins to move upward and use that value as Kg? WPI docs omit the Ks term

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
docs should probably be expanded for the 2-sided tuning algorithm for kg/ks

kG+kS should be the voltage just barely below the point where the elevator creeps upward

kG-kS should be the voltage just barely above the point where the elevator creeps downward

If you know both voltages, you can solve for both kG and kS .

The docs suppose those voltages are the same, and therefor kS = 0 .
@DeltaDizzy for your reading pleasure

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
rkfortner15:

Would disabling the current limit (setting it to 0) be safe during the routine?

Yes, as long as you don’t stall the thing.

posts.name: Ryan Fortner
posts.cooked:
I tried this method just now, and got these values, do they look within a reasonable range?

kG + kS = 0.671 kG - kS = 0.35

Then kG = 0.5105, kS = 0.1605.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Well, do they seem reasonable to you?  Check them against your gearing and motor power and see how much torque they correspond to.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Looks like you’re using default velocity filtering settings on the NEO, which aren’t great for this kind of analysis.  I’d shrink the filter bandwidth.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Oblarg is right, only you can know the answer.

Assuming the units are indeed volts… kS I’ll say seems in the right order of magnititude for a well-greased gearbox and some good bearings. kG is hard to say anything meaningful, it will be highly dependent on the weight of the elevator, and the gear ratio used.

Assuming they are correct, I would say they are good in the context that they imply less than 10% of your available control effort is being used to overcome friction/gravity (and therefor is not available to you for moving the mechanism). If they were closer to 50% of your control effort, I’d say your mechanism is poorly design. But since they aren’t… assuming they’re correct… good job!
